text:
Former President Donald Trump has been 
indicted over his alleged efforts to

overturn the results of the 
2020 presidential election.

And at least 20 people are dead and dozens more 
missing after days of heavy rain in Beijing.

Good morning. I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR 
News, and here are today's top stories:

Former President Donald Trump has been 
indicted on four charges related to

alleged efforts to overturn the 2020 
election. NPR's Jaclyn Diaz has more:

"This indictment is the third criminal case 
against Donald Trump and may be one of the most

serious against the former president. This case 
involves at least six co-conspirators and involves

allegations Trump and his allies interfered in 
a U.S. election in an attempt to cling to power.

"Prosecutors also allege that Trump engaged with 
officials in several states to spread lies that

there was election fraud. Trump's co-conspirators 
have not been named by prosecutors. He's expected

at the federal courthouse in Washington, D.C., 
for his first court appearance on Thursday.
"Jaclyn Diaz, NPR News."

Vice President Harris says she's rejected 
an invitation by Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis

to join a roundtable discussion. It was 
to focus on Florida's new Black history

curriculum. One instruction tells Florida 
middle school students that some enslaved

Black people gained skills that could 
sometimes be used for their personal

benefit. Speaking in Orlando. Harris 
lambasted that as "revisionist history":

"There is no roundtable, no lecture, 
no invitation we will accept to

debate an undeniable fact. There were 
no redeeming qualities of slavery."

Florida Gov. DeSantis accuses the 
Biden administration of misinforming
people on the subject and disparaging his state.

The National Weather Service says the 
dangerous heat wave persists from the

Southwest into the southern Plains 
today and down to the Gulf Coast.

Heat indexes could reach 110 degrees from 
eastern Texas to southern Mississippi.

At least 20 people are dead and dozens of others 
are missing in flooding in China's capital,

Beijing. As NPR's Julia Simon reports, 
climate change can make rain events worse:

"China is experiencing record-breaking 
heat this summer — northwest China saw

temperatures of 126 degrees. Scientists from 
the World Weather Attribution initiative say

this summer's heat wave is virtually impossible 
without human-caused climate change — a hotter

atmosphere can hold more moisture, so 
rainstorms can be more intense. Global

warming primarily comes from humans burning 
fossil fuels. If humans seriously reduce

the use of fossil fuels, scientists say the 
world can avoid more devastating scenarios.
"Julia Simon, NPR News."

Meanwhile, a new typhoon is lashing 
southern Japan. There are reports

from Japan that one person may 
have been killed by the storm.

This typhoon's current path could lead 
it to hit eastern China later this week.
You're listening to NPR News.
